questions.text: A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of headache and impaired vision. She says that she frequently misses turns while driving and hurts herself by accidentally bumping into objects. Confrontational visual field testing shows decreased vision in the left side of both visual fields. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is a lesion in which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The cranial nerve II (CN II) transmits visual information from the retina to the optic chiasm, from where it continues on in the optic tract. Damage to the right CN II can cause complete loss of vision in the ipsilateral eye (right anopsia) as well as a right relative afferent pupillary defect. A lesion here would not be expected as the cause of this patient's left homonymous hemianopsia.

B) INCORRECT:

The x-shaped optic chiasm is the point of partial crossing of fibers from the optic nerve. Damage to this structure would cause bitemporal hemianopsia in both visual fields, as opposed to this patient's left homonymous hemianopsia.
Image Description:

Simulation of right and left visual field

Loss of vision in the temporal half of both the right and left visual fields can be seen. This can occur when the optic chiasma is compressed, often due to tumors of the pituitary gland or craniopharyngioma.

C) INCORRECT:

The cranial nerve II (CN II) transmits visual information from the retina to the optic chiasm, from where it continues on in the optic tract. Damage to the left CN II can cause complete loss of vision in the ipsilateral eye (left anopsia) as well as a left relative afferent pupillary defect. A lesion here would not be expected to cause this patient's left homonymous hemianopsia

D) CORRECT:

The optic tracts relay visual information from the optic chiasm to the ipsilateral lateral geniculate nucleus, from where it continues to the occipital lobe and primary visual cortex. Each tract contains fibers from both the ipsilateral temporal hemiretina and the contralateral nasal hemiretina. The right optic tract, therefore, transmits visual information from the left visual field and vice versa. A right optic tract lesion (e.g., due to compression by an aneurysm, multiple sclerosis, infection, or stroke) has likely caused this patient's left homonymous hemianopsia.
Image Description:

(1) Ipsilateral anopsia
(2) Bitemporal heteronymous hemianopsia
(3) Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia
(4) Contralateral upper homonymous quadrantanopsia
(5) Contralateral lower homonymous quadrantanopsia
(6) Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing
(7) Contralateral homonymous central scotoma

E) INCORRECT:

A left optic tract lesion would cause right homonymous hemianopsia (i.e., on the right side of both visual fields). However, this patient has left homonymous hemianopsia.

F) INCORRECT:

The cranial nerve III (CN III) innervates four of six extraocular muscles and provides parasympathetic stimulation to the ipsilateral eye. Damage to the right oculomotor nerve would cause monocular diplopia of the right eye, resulting in blurring of the visual field rather than vision loss. CN III palsy does not cause homonymous hemianopsia.

G) INCORRECT:

The cranial nerve III (CN III) innervates four of six extraocular muscles and provides parasympathetic stimulation to the ipsilateral eye. Damage to the left oculomotor nerve would cause monocular diplopia of the left eye, resulting in blurring of the visual field rather than vision loss. CN III palsy does not cause homonymous hemianopsia.
questions.hint: A visual deficit involving homologous sides of both visual fields is known as homonymous hemianopsia.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician for decreased vision and worsening headaches since this morning. She has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Pulse is 119/min and irregular. Current medications include ramipril and atorvastatin. Ocular and funduscopic examination shows no abnormalities. The findings of visual field testing are shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery
Occlusion of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Degeneration of the macula can be observed in age-related macular degeneration (AMD), which is subdivided into dry and wet AMD types and causes a gradual loss of central vision and metamorphopsia in the affected eyes, unlike what is seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Impaired perfusion of the retina has been observed in central retinal artery occlusion, which is caused by cardiac emboli in young patients and carotid atherosclerosis in old patients. It presents with an acute painless visual loss in the affected eye; it is usually unilateral and does not spare the macula, unlike in this patient.
Image Description:

Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.

Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

C) CORRECT:

Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery, usually due to emboli from the vertebral vessels, aorta, or heart, results in contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. The macula is spared because the macular tracts have additional blood supply from the middle cerebral arteries.
Image Description:

A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

D) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery causes lateral pontine syndrome. It manifests with vomiting, vertigo, nystagmus, ipsilateral cerebellar ataxia, Horner syndrome, facial muscle paralysis (lower motor neuron lesion type), and sensorineural hearing loss as well as contralateral hemisensory loss, none of which is seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

The middle cerebral artery (MCA) is the most commonly occluded artery in ischemic strokes. Embolic occlusion of the MCA can occasionally lead to the development of contralateral homonymous hemianopia. However, owing to the extensive area of the brain that the MCA supplies, the other signs of stroke, such as contralateral limb weakness and sensory loss, would also be present. Isolated visual field defects are highly unlikely to occur in MCA embolism.

The contralateral homonymous hemianopia in MCA occlusion rarely exhibits macular sparing. This is because the MCA supplies an extensive area of the brain and, thus, occlusion of the MCA affects not only the occipital visual cortex but also the visual pathways.

F) INCORRECT:

Occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery does not affect the visual cortex but causes contralateral limb weakness and sensory loss affecting the lower limb more prominently than the upper limb. Primitive reflexes, like grasp reflexes and rooting reflexes, are also likely to re-emerge. This patient has none of these symptoms.
questions.hint: Visual field testing shows the inability to see the right visual field in either eye (right homonymous hemianopia) with macular sparing, which most commonly results from decreased blood flow to the left occipital lobe.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of diminished vision for several months. Twenty-eight years ago, she was diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus, which has been well controlled with hydroxychloroquine. Fundoscopic examination shows concentric rings of hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation surrounding the fovea bilaterally. Visual field examination of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bitemporal hemianopia describes the loss of vision in the outer halves of the visual field of both eyes. It is typically caused by a compression of the central region of the optic chiasm due to midline pathologies such as aneurysms, pituitary masses, or craniopharyngioma. Treatment with hydroxychloroquine, however, is associated with damage to the retina itself.

B) INCORRECT:

Monocular blindness describes a total visual loss in one eye that can be caused by ischemia of the vessels supplying the retina, retinal vein occlusion, optic nerve compression, or optic nerve neuropathy. Treatment with hydroxychloroquine, however, is not associated with such a complication.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemianopia with macular sparing is a form of homonymous hemianopia in which the central visual field is spared. The visual cortex receives dual blood supply from the posterior cerebral artery (supplies the anterior visual cortex, which processes peripheral vision) and the deep branch of the middle cerebral artery (supplying the occipital pole, which processes information from the central visual field). Infarcts of the PCA would therefore lead to hemianopia with macular sparing. Hydroxychloroquine, in contrast, may specifically damage the macula.
Image Description:

A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

D) CORRECT:

Paracentral scotoma describes an off-center area of visual loss surrounded by normal acuity in the rest of the visual field. As in this case, patients often report difficulty with tasks involving fine visual skills, such as reading, as well as visual color deficits. Paracentral scotoma represents a more advanced stage of retinopathy and is an irreversible complication of hydroxychloroquine whose incidence increases with both the dose and the duration of treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Homonymous hemianopia describes the loss of vision of a unilateral visual field in both eyes. This occurs due to lesions of the optic tract, such as middle cerebral artery infarction, tumors or infections. Treatment with hydroxychloroquine, however, is associated with damage to the retina itself.

F) INCORRECT:

Binasal hemianopia describes the loss of vision in the inner halves of the visual field of both eyes. It is a rare finding caused by bilateral lesions of the outermost fibers of the optic chiasm which hold the uncrossed fibers of the optic nerves. Such lesions may result from aneurysms or tumors. Treatment with hydroxychloroquine, however, is associated with damage to the retina itself.
questions.hint: The concentric rings of hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation (“bull's eye maculopathy”) are an adverse effect of hydroxychloroquine therapy. Hydroxychloroquine maculopathy specifically targets the macular rods and cones but spares these same structures within the fovea.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 1 hour after the sudden onset of a diffuse, dull, throbbing headache. She also reports blurred vision, nausea, and one episode of vomiting. She has a history of poorly controlled hypertension. A photograph of her fundoscopic examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A hemorrhagic lacunar stroke is possible given this patient's age and history of poorly controlled hypertension. However, lacunar strokes manifest with one of five classic stroke syndromes, depending on the location of the infarct (basal ganglia, internal capsule, thalamus, corona radiata, or pons), each of which has characteristic motor and/or sensory findings. This patient does not have focal neurological signs on examination. Moreover, papilledema is not associated with lacunar strokes as these infarcts are, by definition, very small (< 15 mm) in size.

B) INCORRECT:

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) typically manifests with headache in women of childbearing age; obesity is also a significant risk factor. IIH would be very unlikely in this 72-year-old patient. While IIH can manifest with additional symptoms such as papilledema, nausea, and vomiting, which are seen in this patient, its onset would not be acute. Furthermore, IIH often manifests with visual field loss and abducens nerve palsy, neither of which are present here.

C) INCORRECT:

Migraine headaches are usually recurrent, acute, unilateral, throbbing/pulsatile headaches that sometimes include an aura and can also manifest with nausea and vomiting. While this patient has nausea, vomiting, and headache, she has no history of migraine or recurrent headaches, and the new onset of migraine in an older individual is unlikely. Moreover, migraine would not explain this patient's papilledema.

D) INCORRECT:

Giant cell arteritis (GCA) is an important cause of headaches in older patients and can manifest with arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AAION), which causes papilledema and vision loss. However, in patients with AAION, ocular findings are most commonly unilateral rather than bilateral and patients typically have vision loss rather than blurred vision. Moreover, this patient lacks other expected features of GCA (e.g., jaw claudication, temporal tenderness, and constitutional symptoms). Bilateral ocular involvement and permanent vision loss may occur later in the course of the disease.

E) CORRECT:

Hypertensive emergency is the most likely diagnosis in this patient presenting with signs and symptoms of both severe hypertensive retinopathy and hypertensive encephalopathy (headache, nausea, and vomiting). Given her fundoscopic examination and history of poorly controlled hypertension, a significantly elevated blood pressure would be expected in this patient (systolic ≥ 180 mm Hg and/or diastolic ≥ 120 mm Hg). Acute hypertensive nephrosclerosis (formerly referred to as malignant nephrosclerosis) is also commonly seen in hypertensive emergency and manifests with (usually microscopic) hematuria and elevated serum creatinine. Hypertensive emergency requires immediate treatment (often with labetalol or nitroprusside) to prevent further end-organ damage.

Although this patient presents with a dull, throbbing headache as opposed to the classic severe thunderclap headache of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), her overall presentation is also concerning for SAH, which must be promptly investigated and ruled out.

F) INCORRECT:

Epidural hematoma (blood between the skull and dura mater) end-organ in head trauma that damages the middle meningeal artery. History of epidural hematoma classically involves a sudden loss of consciousness, transient return to normal sensorium (the lucid interval), then neurological compromise with the development of focal deficits. Diagnosis is most commonly made with a head CT that shows a biconvex, hyperdense collection. This patient, however, has no history of trauma, making an epidural bleed unlikely.

G) INCORRECT:

Transient ischemic attack (TIA) manifests with acute focal neurological deficits (e.g., unilateral facial weakness) that spontaneously resolve in less than 24 hours (most last < 1 hour). Although this patient is at high risk for TIA (given her age and history of hypertension), she does not present with focal neurological deficits. Furthermore, TIA would not cause papilledema.
questions.hint: Fundoscopic examination shows obscured disc margins, engorged retinal veins, and small hemorrhages around the optic disc margins, which are typical findings of papilledema.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of cough, fatigue, impaired vision, and progressive headaches. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for the last 38 years. After a thorough diagnostic workup, a diagnosis of metastatic lung cancer is made. A schematic overview of the patient's visual fields is shown. This patient is most likely to have a metastatic lesion in which of the following locations of the visual pathway?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The inferior bundle of right optic radiations (right Meyer loop) is located in the right temporal lobe and transmits visual information from the left superior quadrants of the visual field (i.e., from the right lower quadrant of both retinas). Therefore, damage to the right Meyer loop would result in left upper homonymous quadrantanopsia (“pie in the sky”), which does not correspond to the visual defect seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

The inferior bundle of left optic radiations (left Meyer loop) is located in the left temporal lobe and transmits visual information from the right superior quadrants of the visual field (i.e., from the left lower quadrant of both retinas). Therefore, damage to the left Meyer loop would result in right upper homonymous quadrantanopsia (“pie in the sky”), which does not correspond to the visual defect seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The superior bundle of left optic radiations (left dorsal optic radiation) is located in the left parietal lobe and relays information from the right inferior quadrants of the visual field (i.e., from the left superior quadrant of both retinas). Therefore, damage to the left superior bundle of optic radiations results in right lower homonymous quadrantanopsia, which does not correspond to the visual defect seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

The left optic tract transmits information from the right half of each eye's visual field (i.e., from the temporal half of the left retina and nasal half of the right retina). Therefore, damage to the left optic tract would result in right homonymous hemianopsia, which is not seen here.

E) CORRECT:

The visual pathway transmits visual information from the retina to the visual cortex (Brodmann area 17) through the optic nerve, optic chiasm, optic tract, lateral geniculate nucleus, and optic radiations. The superior bundle of right optic radiations (right dorsal optic radiation) relays information from the left inferior quadrants of the visual field, i.e., from the right superior quadrant of both retinas. Therefore, damage to the right superior bundle of optic radiations would produce left lower homonymous quadrantanopsia (“pie on the floor”), as seen here.
Image Description:

(1) Ipsilateral anopsia
(2) Bitemporal heteronymous hemianopsia
(3) Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia
(4) Contralateral upper homonymous quadrantanopsia
(5) Contralateral lower homonymous quadrantanopsia
(6) Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing
(7) Contralateral homonymous central scotoma

F) INCORRECT:

The left macula transmits visual information from the center of the left eye's visual field. Therefore, damage to the left macula (e.g., due to macular degeneration) would result in a left central scotoma, which does not correspond to the visual defect seen in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

The right optic tract transmits information from the left half of each eye's visual field (i.e., from the nasal half of the left retina and temporal half of the right retina). Therefore, damage to the right optic tract would result in left homonymous hemianopsia, which is not seen here.

H) INCORRECT:

The right macula transmits visual information from the center of the right eye's visual field. Therefore, damage to the right macula (e.g., due to macular degeneration) would result in a right central scotoma, which does not correspond to the visual defect seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's visual field defects indicate a lesion in the parietal lobe.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman presents with a 4-day history of decreased vision in her right eye. She has had no eye redness, ocular discharge, or light sensitivity. She reports no history of medical problems, and a review of systems is negative.
On examination, visual acuity is 20/400 in the right eye and 20/20 in the left eye. A right afferent pupillary defect is noted. The patient’s extraocular movements are full, but she has pronounced pain whenever she attempts to move her right eye. On funduscopic examination, the optic nerve appears normal, with crisp margins, no hemorrhages, and no cotton-wool spots.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Perform MRI of the brain and orbits, with and without contrast

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Optic neuritis, which refers to inflammation and demyelination of the optic nerve, disproportionately affects younger women. Affected patients typically present with unilateral decreased vision, pain with extraocular movement, a relative afferent pupillary defect (the pupil dilates during the swinging-flashlight test), diminished color vision, and optic nerves that appear normal on funduscopic examination.

Optic neuritis is associated with multiple sclerosis. Consequently, any patient presenting with new-onset optic neuritis should undergo MRI of the brain and orbits, with and without contrast, to assess for T2-weighted and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery lesions consistent with multiple sclerosis. An MRI would also help rule out other causes of this clinical presentation, such as retro-orbital tumors.

In addition to undergoing MRI, patients experiencing an initial episode of unilateral optic neuritis are often admitted for treatment with intravenous glucocorticoids. They typically receive intravenous methylprednisolone for 3 days followed by an oral prednisone taper for 11 days. This approach can shorten the time to visual recovery but does not affect long-term clinical outcomes.

Key learning point: Patients presenting with a first episode of unilateral optic neuritis should undergo MRI of the brain and orbits to determine the risk for multiple sclerosis.

B) INCORRECT:

CT cannot readily detect the findings typical of multiple sclerosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral glucocorticoids have been associated with an increased risk of recurrence when not preceded by intravenous glucocorticoids and should therefore not be offered as initial treatment in this setting.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment and measurement of inflammatory activity are not indicated in cases of new-onset unilateral optic neuritis. An infectious and inflammatory workup should be considered in cases of bilateral optic neuritis or in cases of optic-nerve edema where the diagnosis is not straightforward.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment and measurement of inflammatory activity are not indicated in cases of new-onset unilateral optic neuritis. An infectious and inflammatory workup should be considered in cases of bilateral optic neuritis or in cases of optic-nerve edema where the diagnosis is not straightforward.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old girl presents with a 4-day history of decreased vision in her right eye. She has had no eye redness, ocular discharge, or light sensitivity. She has no history of medical problems, and a review of systems is negative.
On examination, visual acuity is 20/400 in the right eye and 20/20 in the left eye. A right afferent pupillary defect is noted. The patient’s extraocular movements are full, but she has pronounced pain whenever she attempts to move her right eye. On funduscopic examination, the optic nerve appears normal, with crisp margins, no hemorrhages, and no cotton-wool spots.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Perform MRI of the brain and orbits, with and without contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There are no clinical trials for the treatment of pediatric optic neuritis, and current recommendations are based on the Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial in adults. Patients experiencing an initial episode of unilateral optic neuritis should not be offered treatment with oral glucocorticoids, because this treatment has been associated with an increased risk of recurrence. However, if the patient chooses a glucocorticoid treatment regimen, 3 days of intravenous methylprednisolone is recommended, followed by a rapid oral taper; this approach can shorten the time to visual recovery but does not affect the long-term clinical outcome.

B) CORRECT:

Optic neuritis, which refers to inflammation and demyelination of the optic nerve, disproportionately affects younger women. Classic symptoms include unilateral decreased vision, pain with extraocular movement, a relative afferent pupillary defect (the pupil dilates during the swinging-flashlight test), diminished color vision, and optic nerves that appear normal on funduscopic examination.

Optic neuritis is associated with multiple sclerosis. Consequently, any patient presenting with new-onset optic neuritis should undergo MRI of the brain and orbits, with and without contrast, to assess for T2-weighted and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery lesions consistent with multiple sclerosis.

Key learning point: Patients presenting with a first episode of unilateral optic neuritis should undergo MRI of the brain and orbits to determine the risk for multiple sclerosis.

C) INCORRECT:

CT cannot readily detect the findings typical of multiple sclerosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment is not indicated in cases of new-onset unilateral optic neuritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Measurement of inflammatory activity is not indicated in cases of new-onset unilateral optic neuritis. An infectious and inflammatory workup should be considered in cases of bilateral optic neuritis or in cases of optic-nerve edema where the diagnosis is not straightforward.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with a 4-day history of decreased vision in her right eye. On examination, visual acuity is 20/400 in the right eye and 20/20 in the left eye. A right afferent pupillary defect is noted. The patient’s extraocular movements are full, but she has pronounced pain whenever she attempts to move her right eye. On funduscopic examination, the optic nerve appears normal, with crisp margins. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform MRI of the brain and orbits, with and without contrast

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Optic neuritis, which refers to inflammation and demyelination of the optic nerve, disproportionately affects younger women. Affected patients typically present with unilateral decreased vision, pain with extraocular movement, a relative afferent pupillary defect (the pupil dilates during the swinging-flashlight test), diminished color vision, and optic nerves that appear normal on funduscopic examination.

Optic neuritis is associated with multiple sclerosis. Consequently, any patient presenting with new-onset optic neuritis should undergo MRI of the brain and orbits, with and without contrast, to assess for T2-weighted and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery lesions consistent with multiple sclerosis. An MRI would also help rule out other causes of this clinical presentation, such as retro-orbital tumors.

In addition to undergoing MRI, patients experiencing an initial episode of unilateral optic neuritis are often admitted for treatment with intravenous glucocorticoids. They typically receive intravenous methylprednisolone for 3 days followed by an oral prednisone taper for 11 days. This approach can shorten the time to visual recovery but does not affect long-term clinical outcomes.

Key learning point: Patients presenting with a first episode of unilateral optic neuritis should undergo MRI of the brain and orbits to determine the risk for multiple sclerosis.

B) INCORRECT:

CT cannot readily detect the findings typical of optic neuritis or multiple sclerosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral glucocorticoids have been associated with an increased risk of recurrence when not preceded by intravenous glucocorticoids and should therefore not be offered as initial treatment in this setting.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment and measurement of inflammatory activity are not indicated in cases of new-onset unilateral optic neuritis. An infectious and inflammatory workup should be considered in cases of bilateral optic neuritis or in cases of optic-nerve edema where the diagnosis is not straightforward.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment and measurement of inflammatory activity are not indicated in cases of new-onset unilateral optic neuritis. An infectious and inflammatory workup should be considered in cases of bilateral optic neuritis or in cases of optic-nerve edema where the diagnosis is not straightforward.
questions.hint: This patient's findings raise suspicion for optic neuritis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because of left-sided neck swelling that has slowly progressed over the past 4 weeks. He has no history of serious illness. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F). Physical examination shows a nontender, mobile mass in the left submandibular region with overlying erythema. A biopsy of the mass shows caseating granulomas. Pharmacotherapy with azithromycin and ethambutol is initiated. This patient is most likely to experience which of the following adverse effects related to ethambutol use?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rifampin is an antibiotic commonly used to treat tuberculosis that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by preventing transcription (mRNA synthesis). Adverse effects include flu-like symptoms, hepatotoxicity, and a characteristic orange discoloration of body fluids (e.g., urine, tears). Ethambutol does not lead to orange discoloration of urine.

B) INCORRECT:

Many medications can cause acute kidney injury, including, in rare cases, ethambutol. However, this side effect would be more likely with streptomycin, an aminoglycoside that can be used to treat mycobacterial infections and works by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis and damaging the bacterial cell wall. Additional adverse effects of streptomycin include ototoxicity, neuromuscular blockade (ataxia), and nephrotoxicity. Ethambutol is more likely to cause another side effect.

C) CORRECT:

Optic neuritis is an important adverse effect of ethambutol and can manifest with blurred vision, decreased visual acuity, and color blindness. Irreversible blindness may develop. The mechanism of ethambutol-induced optic neuritis is not known but there is a dose-dependent correlation in risk of occurrence.

D) INCORRECT:

Methemoglobinemia is a serious adverse effect of dapsone, an antibiotic that can be used for the treatment of Mycobacterium leprae infection (e.g. leprosy). Ethambutol is not known to cause methemoglobinemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Peripheral neuropathy is commonly observed with isoniazid, a prodrug activated by bacterial catalase-peroxidase that inhibits mycolic acid synthesis, a vital component of mycobacterial cell walls. Isoniazid is used mainly to treat tuberculosis. Adverse effects include vitamin B6 deficiency (a cofactor in the biosynthesis of important neurotransmitters), which can lead to peripheral neuropathy. Peripheral neuropathy is not a known adverse effect of ethambutol.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation (unilateral, nontender lymphadenitis) and biopsy findings (caseating granulomas) suggest an infection with nontuberculous mycobacteria. Ethambutol works by inhibiting arabinosyltransferase, an enzyme involved in the polymerization and subsequent synthesis of mycobacterial cell walls.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 4-day history of decreased vision in her right eye. On examination, visual acuity is 20/400 in the right eye and 20/20 in the left eye. There is a right afferent pupillary defect. Extraocular movements are full, but she experiences significant pain with movement of her right eye. Funduscopic examination shows a normal-appearing optic disc with crisp margins. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment and measurement of inflammatory activity are not indicated in cases of new-onset unilateral optic neuritis. An infectious and inflammatory workup should be considered in cases of bilateral optic neuritis or in cases of optic-nerve edema where the diagnosis is not straightforward.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral glucocorticoids have been associated with an increased risk of recurrence when not preceded by intravenous glucocorticoids and should therefore not be offered as initial treatment in this setting.

C) CORRECT:

Optic neuritis is associated with multiple sclerosis. Consequently, any patient presenting with new-onset optic neuritis should undergo MRI of the brain and orbits, with and without contrast, to assess for T2-weighted and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery lesions consistent with multiple sclerosis. An MRI would also help rule out other causes of this clinical presentation, such as retro-orbital tumors.

In addition to undergoing MRI, patients experiencing an initial episode of unilateral optic neuritis are often admitted for treatment with intravenous glucocorticoids. They typically receive intravenous methylprednisolone for 3 days followed by an oral prednisone taper for 11 days. This approach can shorten the time to visual recovery but does not affect long-term clinical outcomes.

Key learning point: Patients presenting with a first episode of unilateral optic neuritis should undergo MRI of the brain and orbits to determine the risk for multiple sclerosis.

D) INCORRECT:

CT cannot readily detect the findings typical of optic neuritis or multiple sclerosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment and measurement of inflammatory activity are not indicated in cases of new-onset unilateral optic neuritis. An infectious and inflammatory workup should be considered in cases of bilateral optic neuritis or in cases of optic-nerve edema where the diagnosis is not straightforward.
questions.hint: Optic neuritis, which refers to inflammation and demyelination of the optic nerve, primarily affects young women. Patients typically present with sudden, unilateral vision loss, pain on eye movement, a relative afferent pupillary defect (the pupil dilates during the swinging‑flashlight test), and reduced color perception. In cases of retrobulbar neuritis without papillitis, the optic disc appears normal on funduscopic exam.

questions.text: You are seeing a 4-year-old boy brought to your clinic by his mother because of left-sided neck swelling that has gradually increased over the past 4 weeks. He has no history of serious illness. His temperature is 38.0°C. On examination, there is a nontender, mobile mass in the left submandibular region with overlying erythema. Biopsy of the mass reveals caseating granulomas. He is started on azithromycin and ethambutol. Which one of the following adverse effects is most likely to occur with ethambutol use in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Peripheral neuropathy due to vitamin B6 deficiency is commonly observed with isoniazid, which is used mainly to treat tuberculosis. Peripheral neuropathy due to ethambutol is very rare and typically associated with higher doses or prolonged use, particularly in individuals with renal impairment. A different adverse effect occurs more frequently.

B) INCORRECT:

Many medications can cause acute kidney injury, including, in rare cases, ethambutol. However, this side effect would be more likely with streptomycin, an aminoglycoside that can be used to treat mycobacterial infections. Additional adverse effects of streptomycin include ototoxicity, neuromuscular blockade (ataxia), and nephrotoxicity. Ethambutol is more likely to cause another side effect.

C) INCORRECT:

Methemoglobinemia is a serious adverse effect of dapsone, an antibiotic that can be used for the treatment of Mycobacterium leprae infection. Ethambutol is not known to cause methemoglobinemia.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation (unilateral, nontender lymphadenitis) and biopsy findings (caseating granulomas) suggest an infection with nontuberculous mycobacteria. Treatment typically involves a macrolide (e.g., azithromycin, clarithromycin) plus ethambutol, with rifampin or rifabutin added for disseminated or more severe disease. Optic neuritis is an important adverse effect of ethambutol and can manifest with blurred vision, decreased visual acuity, and color blindness (particularly red–green dyschromatopsia). Irreversible blindness may develop. The mechanism of ethambutol-induced optic neuritis is not known but there is a dose-dependent correlation in risk of occurrence.

Key learning point: Ethambutol can cause optic neuritis, which may present as blurred vision, decreased visual acuity, and color blindness.

E) INCORRECT:

Rifampin is an antibiotic commonly used to treat mycobacterial infections. Adverse effects include flu-like symptoms, hepatotoxicity, and a characteristic orange discoloration of body fluids (e.g., urine, tears). Ethambutol does not cause urine to become orange.
questions.hint: Chloroquine can also cause this particular adverse effect.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with a 2-day history of vision loss in her left eye and pain that worsens with eye movement. She reports difficulty distinguishing colors and describes her vision as "looking through frosted glass." Visual acuity is 20/200 in the affected eye with normal fundoscopic findings. On swinging-flashlight test, when light is shone on the unaffected right eye, both pupils constrict normally, but when the light is rapidly transferred to the affected left eye, both pupils dilate. She denies headache, nausea, or systemic symptoms. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: MRI head and orbits with and without IV contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although indirect fundoscopy can provide additional examination details, it is not the most appropriate next step; fundoscopy may be normal in retrobulbar neuritis, which involves inflammation of the retrobulbar part of the optic nerve. As this patient's clinical presentation already strongly suggests optic neuritis, the priority is neuroimaging to evaluate for demyelinating lesions and establish the underlying etiology.

B) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture for CSF analysis is commonly performed to support a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis (MS) and exclude other inflammatory conditions, but it is not a first-line diagnostic test for suspected optic neuritis. The finding of oligoclonal bands in CSF but not in blood supports a diagnosis of MS, but CSF is typically obtained after initial neuroimaging has been performed to identify demyelinating lesions.

C) INCORRECT:

High-dose corticosteroids such as IV methylprednisolone are used for the treatment of acute optic neuritis and may improve recovery time. However, treatment should not be initiated until a diagnostic workup has been completed to evaluate for underlying multiple sclerosis or other causes.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – MRI head and orbits with and without IV contrast is the first-line imaging study for suspected optic neuritis. This patient presents with classic findings, including subacute monocular vision loss, orbital pain with eye movement, dyschromatopsia, and a positive swinging-flashlight test indicating a relative afferent pupillary defect. MRI can identify demyelinating lesions as well as help to establish whether they represent an isolated episode or are due to multiple sclerosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Temporal artery biopsy is indicated for suspected giant cell arteritis, which typically affects older patients and manifests with systemic symptoms, including headache, jaw claudication, and constitutional symptoms. This patient's clinical presentation and age are not consistent with giant cell arteritis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with progressive vision loss in her right eye over two days. She describes pain behind the eye that worsens with movement and notes that colors appear faded. She denies trauma, photophobia, headache, or discharge. Vital signs are BP, 120/72; P, 76; R, 14; T, 37.0°C (98.6°F). Visual acuity is 20/200 in the right eye and 20/20 in the left. A right relative afferent pupillary defect is present. Which of the following diagnoses best explains this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient's presentation is typical for optic neuritis, which is most commonly associated with multiple sclerosis. Subacute, painful monocular vision loss with decreased color perception and a relative afferent pupillary defect strongly suggests demyelinating disease. Recognition in the ED allows appropriate neurology referral for diagnostic imaging and management.

B) INCORRECT:

Anterior uveitis causes ocular pain and blurred vision but typically manifests with redness, photophobia, and tearing.

C) INCORRECT:

Central serous retinopathy occurs in young adults but produces painless central vision loss or distortion, often described as a dark spot or wavy lines. The presence of pain with eye movement makes this diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute angle-closure glaucoma manifests with severe eye pain, halos around lights, headache, nausea, and a fixed, mid-dilated pupil. It is rare in a young patient and causes intense, constant pain rather than pain associated with eye movement.

E) INCORRECT:

Retinal migraine causes transient, reversible monocular vision loss that typically lasts less than one hour and is associated with headache. Progressive vision loss over two days accompanied by retrobulbar pain is inconsistent with migraine-related pathology.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sudden-onset loss of vision. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, atenolol, metformin, and glipizide. Ophthalmologic examination shows a visual field defect in the bilateral right upper quadrants. A lesion in which of the following labeled sites in the schematic overview of the visual pathway is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Damage to the left optic nerve causes ipsilateral anopia (so of the left eye). A lesion here is unlikely in this patient, who has at least some vision in both eyes.

B) INCORRECT:

A lesion in this region would damage nerve fibers from the temporal part of the retina of the left eye, which would cause nasal hemianopia of the left eye.

C) INCORRECT:

Injury at the decussation of optic nerve fibers at the optic chiasm causes bitemporal hemianopia. Pituitary lesions (e.g., pituitary adenoma, pituitary apoplexy) and saccular aneurysms classically cause this visual field defect.

D) INCORRECT:

Damage in this region, the left optic tract, causes a contralateral (so right-sided) homonymous hemianopia. Stroke, tumors, surgery, and congenital defects may cause damage to the optic tract.

E) CORRECT:

This location corresponds to the Meyer loop. Disruptions in this segment of the visual pathway classically produce contralateral superior homonymous quadrantanopia. Common etiologies include stroke involving the middle cerebral artery, which is likely in this patient with hypertension and diabetes, as well as mass effect (e.g., tumors).
Image Description:

(1) Ipsilateral anopsia
(2) Bitemporal heteronymous hemianopsia
(3) Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia
(4) Contralateral upper homonymous quadrantanopsia
(5) Contralateral lower homonymous quadrantanopsia
(6) Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing
(7) Contralateral homonymous central scotoma

F) INCORRECT:

Injuries to the left dorsal optic radiation will classically produce contralateral (so right-sided) lower homonymous quadrantanopia. Lesions of the parietal lobe, most commonly stroke involving the MCA, are implicated in the development of this type of visual defect. The patient in this stem, however, has defects in the superior visual fields.

G) INCORRECT:

An injury to the left central bundle of the optic radiation would cause either contralateral (so right-sided) hemianopia with macular sparing (typically caused by a posterior cerebral artery infarct) or complete contralateral homonymous hemianopia. The patient described here has a single quadrant defect, which does not fit with either of these injury presentations.
Image Description:

A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)
questions.hint: Superior homonymous quadrantanopia indicates a lesion of the Meyer loop, which carries information from the retina through the temporal lobe.
